title: For Constantius' almost incessant wars against the Persians between 337 and 360 (Festus, 26), with an English translation of the sources, vid

note: He allowed Tigranes to retain his throne but deprived him of his foreign conquests ( Plut. Pomp. 38; Appian, Mith. 114-115; Dio, 36.51-53; 37.7a; Velleius, 11.373 ff; Val. Max. 5.19; Flor. 1.40.27; Ammianus, 14.8.10).
title: Further flattery of Constantius by comparing him with Pompey the Great. In 66 B.C., by virtue of the Lex Manilla, Pompey was sent east to fight Mithridates of Pontus and his son-in-law Tigranes of Armenia. He defeated Mithridates that year and the king committed suicide in 63 B.C. Meanwhile (64 B.C.) Pompey invaded Armenia and forced Tigranes to surrender
